Award.AwardTitle: REU SITE: Undergraduate Biology Education Research Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Undergraduate Biology Education Research (UBER) REU Site engages undergraduates in studying important issues specific to the teaching and learning of biology, with mentorship from faculty in the Division of Biological Sciences and the Mathematics and Science Education Department at the University of Georgia. The goals of this nine-week summer program are to develop undergraduates' knowledge and skills in biology education research, encourage undergraduates to pursue doctoral study of biology teaching and learning, expand the diversity of the talent pool in biology education research by strategically recruiting and mentoring underrepresented and disadvantaged students, strengthen and expand collaborations among faculty and students in education and life sciences, and contribute to the development of theory and knowledge about biology education in ways that can inform undergraduate biology instruction.

A programmatic effort to introduce undergraduates to the discipline of biology education research is unprecedented nationwide. Biology education research as a discipline is quite young, and systematic involvement of undergraduates has not been part of the culture or practice in biology or education. UBER aims to promote cultural change that expands the involvement of undergraduates in biology education research and raises awareness among undergraduates that biology teaching and learning are compelling foci for study that can be pursued at the graduate level and via various career paths. UBER utilizes a combined strategy of broad and strategic recruiting to attract underrepresented minority students as well as students who do not have access to biology education research opportunities at their own institutions. Evaluation plans involve tracking UBER participants over time to understand the trajectories of students who complete undergraduate training in biology education research.

Significant co-funding of this project is provided by the Division of Biological Infrastructure in the NSF Directorate for Biological Sciences in recognition of the importance of educational research in the discipline of biology. The Division of Undergraduate Education and the Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings also provides co-funding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The undergraduate biology education research (UBER) research experience for undergraduates (REU) program was developed and implemented at University of Georgia (UGA). Participants (known as UBER fellows) engaged in an intensive nine-week summer program to investigate important issues in biology teaching and learning. UBER fellows studied diverse topics such as the development of problem solving skills in biology students, faculty learning communities to support teaching innovations, and the use of three-dimensional animations to help students learn about the science of nutrition. UBER fellows collaborated with UGA faculty members with expertise in biology education research. These UBER mentors provided training and mentorship that allowed UBER fellows to take ownership of their research projects. UBER fellows also developed knowledge of and skills in biology education research through participation in weekly professional development workshops, weekly discussions of biology education research papers, and weekly research group meetings. UBER fellows also engaged in networking events where they talked with researchers about careers and career paths in biology and biology education research. Through these experiences and their research projects, UBER fellows contributed to knowledge and theory about biology education, which will help improve undergraduate teaching and learning in biology. UBER fellows shared their findings widely through publications and presentations at regional, national, and international meetings.

The UBER REU program contributed to the diversity of the talent pool in biology and biology education research. Highly qualified and diverse undergraduates were recruited from across the country to join the program. UBER fellows included 45.4% students from underrepresented minority groups or disabled students, and 53.4% students from schools with limited research opportunities. UBER fellows were encouraged to pursue graduate studies in biology teaching and learning. Over 80% of participants reported that the program increased their interest in pursuing a Ph.D. in biology or biology education research. Of the students who had graduated at the end of the third year of the program, over 90% are pursuing career paths related to biology and biology education. The impact of the UBER program is expected to be exponential in the future, as UBER fellows become biology instructors and researchers who will apply what they have learned from this REU in their future careers.
